title: death
comment: Death in its various aspects is seen by Scripture as the opposite of God-given life.

children.title: death, natural
children.comment: The end of life in the present world.

children.title: Death is natural to humanity as part of the created world
Death is a result of Adam's sin

primaryrefs.comment: There is a tension between this text and those which suggest that death is a natural aspect of being human. Some suggest that the death referred to here is spiritual rather than physical.

children.title: Death is universal
None can escape death
Death comes to all kinds of people
Only two people did not die

primaryrefs.comment: Enoch and Elijah died in the sense that their bodies were transformed from being suited to earthly life to life in heaven. They anticipated the death of Jesus Christ, whose body was not corrupted but transformed, and the transition to the new world of those who are alive when Jesus Christ comes again.

children.title: Death is irreversible

primaryrefs.comment: The idea of reincarnation, that after death people repeatedly return to this life in a lower or higher form, is incompatible with death being once for all and an entrance into heaven or hell after the judgment.

children.title: Death is an aspect of human frailty
Death occurs when God determines it
The means of death
Through old age
Through disease and accident
Through violence
As a judgment by God
Through a legal penalty
The prospect of death affects human attitudes and values
Life is short
People fear death
People should prepare for death
The expectation of death is an incentive to serve God
The expectation of death is an incentive to hold material blessings lightly
Death is sometimes desired to escape problems
Death was defeated by Jesus Christ
There is no death in heaven
death, of believers
children.comment: Believers in Jesus Christ will depart from this present life to the joy of God's presence.

children.title: Death is a normal experience for believers
Death can be a blessing
Because of the prospect of heaven
Because it brings relief from trouble and problems
At death believers are with Christ
They are in his presence
They are safe and secure

primaryrefs.comment: The second death is the final banishment of unbelievers from God's presence.

children.title: They have the prospect of a new order of things
The defeat of death
Death is vanquished for believers
Death is to be reversed in resurrection
children.precomment: Though some of the above passages suggest that eternal life in Jesus Christ's presence is experienced immediately at death, others such as the following link these blessings with resurrection at the final coming of Jesus Christ:

children.title: The death of believers is likened to sleep
Implying rest, renewing and awaking

primaryrefs.comment: Sleep does not imply lack of consciousness but rather rest, renewing and awaking. In the NT it is only used of believers.

children.title: Implying peace and comfort

primaryrefs.comment: Abraham's side suggests a welcome to a place of peace and protection.

children.title: Death and the recognition of others

seealsos.comment: ``gathered to his people'' (literally ``to his father's kin'') is a common OT expression and implies continued existence together

children.title: Believers can face death without fear
They die in relationship with God
They die trusting the Lord
They receive comfort in facing death
In death they can glorify God
In this believers are to be envied
Believers often hated the idea of death
Martyred believers are specially honoured in Scripture
death, of unbelievers
children.comment: The departure from the present life of unrepentant people to await final banishment from God.

children.title: Death is inevitable
The premature death of unbelievers is the consequence of sin

primaryrefs.comment: OT writers, for whom God's blessing on the righteous occurs mostly in the present life, often saw early or sudden death as divine judgment on the wicked.

children.title: Aspects of the death of unbelievers
They die unforgiven
They die without hope
God has no pleasure in their death
Descriptions of the death of unbelievers
Being destroyed
Perishing
Being in fire
Being in darkness
The consequences of the death of unbelievers
The intermediate state of awaiting judgment
The judgment
The eternal consequences
The challenge of the death of unbelievers
The call to prepare
The only escape is through Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Death for believers is swallowed up in life, so that they are never personally aware of the pain and sting of death (compare Jn 11:26).

children.title: death, spiritual
children.comment: A condition in this life of alienation from God because of sin. It leads ultimately to the ``second death'', the permanent separation of unbelievers from God.

children.title: Spiritual death means alienation from God in this life
Spiritual death is a result of Adam's sin
Symptoms of spiritual death
Spiritual ignorance
A mind controlled by the sinful nature
Unbelief
Living in sinful pleasures
Acting in ways that lead to death
Spiritual death leads ultimately to the ``second death''
A church may be spiritually dead
Deliverance from spiritual death is only through Jesus Christ
